person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_377.name: JohnMayow
person_377.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

person_387.name: John JoachimBecher
person_387.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_370.name: AndreasLibavius
person_370.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_166.name: BryanHiggins
person_166.description: Irish chemist and natural philosopher who developed a form of the atomic theory of matter. Worked in London, St Petersburg and Jamacia. Uncle of William Higgins.

person_165.name: WilliamHiggins
person_165.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_931.name: PierreBayen
person_931.description: French chemist best known for experiments on water toxicity. He also performed experiements related to the discovery of oxygen.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_922.name: AdairCrawford
person_922.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

person_683.name: EdmundGoodwyn
person_683.description: Physician who studied with Thomas Beddoes at the University of Edinburgh.

person_932.name: CornelisDrebbel
person_932.description: Dutch engineer and inventor. He was the builder of the first operational submarine in 1620 and an innovator who contributed to the development of measurement and control systems, optics and chemistry.

otherwork_257.name: Micrographia: or Some Physiological Descriptions of Minute Bodies Made by Magnifying Glasses. With Observations and Inquiries Thereupon
otherwork_257.author: Robert Hooke

otherwork_258.name: Essays de Jean Rey sur la Recerche de la cause pour laquelle l'Estain et le Plomb augmentent de poids quand on les calcine,
otherwork_258.author: Jean Rey

otherwork_202.name: A Comparative View of the Phlogistic and Antiphlogistic Theories
otherwork_202.author: William Higgins
